awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Opportunities in Unmanned Systems Foundations and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The "Unmanned Systems Foundation and Application" Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Nebraska offers an intensive and comprehensive research experience to ten undergraduate students per year in the context of unmanned systems, a rapidly growing field of scientific and technological research. A team of faculty experts from the Nebraska Intelligent MoBile Unmanned Systems Lab (NIMBUS Lab) provides individual mentoring for ten weeks to instill the foundations of research methodology and to conduct hands-on research activities on a variety of unmanned systems applications. The participants engage in professional development activities to better prepare them for Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics (STEM) careers.  Students from computer science, computer engineering, mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, and other related majors are considered. Particular attention is given to students from underrepresented groups and from institutions in the Midwest that lack research opportunities, in order to support broader educational goals and diversity in the STEM workforce.

Each REU participant's research project focuses on unmanned systems with topics including: attitude control of nanosatellites, behavior studies of robots in complex environments around humans, characterizing and developing vehicles for atmospheric profiling, and asset management during wildfires with unmanned aerial vehicles.  Projects build on ongoing faculty research, but are crafted for participants to gain experience in all aspects of research, from conducting a literature review and prototyping, to understanding the broad potential impact of the technology being investigated. Participant development will be quantified by closely assessing their growth through the REU experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This site has helped drive advances on the individual research projects of the four site PIs, including two CAREER awards. This REU site has contributed to the publication of three conference papers and two journal articles with REU students as co-authors.

Broader impacts: This site has supported thirty-nine students, including seven S-STEM scholars, in beginning their research careers with roughly 50% of these students continuing on to graduate school.

Across all years we had 267 applicants with 29% female and 27% from groups historically underrepresented in computing (URG). In 2018 we had 54 undergraduate student applicants; among them 24% identified as female and 24% were from URG. Due to issues in switching applications, we do not have application demographics numbers for 2019, but do have summary statistics from our summative evaluation reported above. In 2021 we had 71 applicants; among them 37% were female and 37% from URG. In 2022 we had 45 applicants with 37% of them not identifying as male and 35% of them from URG.

In our first year we had four students accept our offer to join our REU site and we accepted an additional student from the Computing Research Association’s Distributed REU program. Due to our limited advertisement time in our first year and delays in receiving our funding, our acceptances were limited. We had 50% women in the cohort (with an additional DREU woman) and no students from URG. 75% of our students came from institutions with limited opportunities for research experiences and 50% of them went on to attend graduate school. We are still in touch with two of the students and know that they are working in industry.

Our second year was much better advertised and we were able to start making commitments to students earlier, so we ended up with a more diverse student group. Within our group of ten students, we still achieved 50% women and were also able to host 30% students from URG. Of these students 50% had never previously participated in a research experience and at the end of the program 70% intended to attend graduate school. We provided recommendation letters for these 70% of students and 20% of them went on to attend graduate school with us at UNL. 50% of students from this cohort are currently involved in a PhD program.

In our third year we accepted twelve students (including four S-STEM scholars on a supplement). Within this group, we had 50% students who did not identify as male and 25% students from URG. Of these students 50% had never participated in a research experience. We accepted younger students in this cohort, including four sophomores and two freshmen, so the students were a bit further out from considering graduate school. With this in mind, we are aware that two of the students from this cohort are attending graduate school and helped them with their application development.

In our fourth year we had 12 students accept our offer, while 2 later withdrew prior to arriving on campus. Of these students we had four Black or African American students, one Hispanic or Latino student, 1 Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander student. Two of the students who withdrew were Black or African American, which led to less students from URG than we had anticipated. For students who ultimately participated in our program, we had 30% students from URG, 30% female participants, 50% of students participating from institutions with limited research opportunities, and 10% of students participating from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). We are planning to coordinate with these students as they apply for graduate school and support them in ways that we have in prior cohorts.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2023
Modified by: Brittany A Duncan
